poem:
**Notting Hill, Reimagined**

Concrete, not confetti, lines the street,  
where romance once took its easy seat.  
In the shadow of blockades, footsteps pause,  
a lover's chase diverted by modern cause.  
In the struggle of steel and stone,  
soft hearts learn to navigate alone.  
Past films fade, touched by the times,  
as love adapts to new paradigms.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘A sign of how we live now’: friction in Notting Hill over counter-terrorism barriers If Richard Curtis had shot his romcom classic Notting Hill over the past month, things might have turned out very differently. Julia Roberts would have had to stumble past huge concrete blocks while losing the hand of her British sweetheart and Hugh Grant might have missed his departing lover as he struggled to exit the area in an overstuffed Peugeot 406.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
